# 27.2 R Markdown basics

  1.  YAML header  
  1.  Code chunks  
  1.  Text mixed with simple text  
  
These basic components are seen in the following example:

The following YAML header sets up a document to have the code available but hidden:

`title: "Diamond sizes"`    
`output:`      
`html_document:`  
`code_folding: hide`  
    
The first code chunk often contains libraries  

`{r setup, include = FALSE}`  
`knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)`  
`library(tidyverse)`  

We can then mix text with code.  


# 27.3 Formatting in RMarkdown  

## Italics, bold, and super and subscripts  

* *italics One*  
* _italics Two_  
* **bold One**  
* __bold Two__  
* subscript~2~  
* superscript^2^  

## Lists  
### Unordered  

* One  
* Two  

### Ordered

  1.  One
      i)  i
      i)  ii
  1.  Two

# Scatterplot of miles per gallon on car weight
## Built-in R data set

# Code blocks

## Inline

The number of rows in the mtcars tibble is: `r nrow(mtcars)`.

## Graph

```{r mpg versus wt, echo = TRUE}
mtcars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) +
    geom_point(color = "red", alpha = 0.5) + 
    geom_smooth(method = "loess", color = "lightgreen", se = FALSE) +
    geom_smooth(method = "lm", color = "lightblue", se = FALSE) +
    labs(
      title = "The relationship between mileage and weight is not linear",
      x = "Weight in Thousands of Pounds",
      y = "Miles Per Gallon"
    )
```  

## Warnings and Messages

```{r histogram, message = TRUE}
mtcars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = mpg)) +
    geom_histogram()
```
